description: Fourth pass of influence analysis: compares the author's use of each thinker against the thinker's actual positions. Verifies hypotheses, assesses fidelity, and documents misappropriations.
researcher_question: How faithfully does the author represent the thinkers they cite?

engagements.hypothesis_id: string - which hypothesis was being tested
engagements.author_claim: string - what the author claims the thinker says/means
engagements.thinker_actual: string - what the thinker actually argues
engagements.analysis: string - detailed analysis of the gap (if any)
engagements.significance: high | medium | low - how important is this discrepancy

meta.most_problematic_thinker: string - thinker with most fidelity issues
meta.most_faithful_thinker: string - thinker with most faithful usage

extraction.core_question: Does the author's use of each thinker match what the thinker actually argued?
extraction_steps: PAIR CLAIMS: Match author's claims about thinkers with sampled passages
COMPARE: Assess agreement or divergence between author's use and thinker's actual position
CLASSIFY FIDELITY: Rate as faithful, selective, distorted, or invented
ANALYZE GAPS: For non-faithful uses, explain the nature of the discrepancy
ASSESS SIGNIFICANCE: Determine how important each discrepancy is
extraction.special_instructions: Be rigorous but fair. 'Selective' means choosing real aspects but ignoring others. 'Distorted' means getting it partially wrong. 'Invented' means attributing positions the thinker never held. Some creative reinterpretation may be legitimate - note these as 'contested'.

id_examples.to: Foucault on discipline: DISTORTED - author conflates surveillance with punishment

concretization.naming_guidance: Use thinker name, topic, and fidelity level
